The Ed, Edd n Eddy Movie is a 2004 Canadian-American traditional 2-D hand-drawn animated adventure comedy crossover film based on Cartoon Network's animated television series Ed, Edd n Eddy and Foster's Home for Imaginary Friends. The film was directed by Danny Antonucci, produced by Cartoon Network Studios and distributed by Warner Bros. Feature Animation, with animation provided by Rough Draft Studios Korea in South Korea. The events of the film take places during the fifth season of Ed, Edd n Eddy and the second season of Foster's Home for Imaginary Friends. The film stars the voices of Bill Farmer, Samuel Vincent, Billy West, Tom Kenny, Charlie Schlatter, Russi Taylor, Kath Soucie, Dee Bradley Baker, Kerri Kenney-Silver, Pat Musick, Tress MacNeille, Tara Strong and Keith David reprising their respective roles from the series, while being joined by new actors which include Andrea Libman, Michael Clarke Duncan, Dana Snyder, Jim Conroy, Ricky Gervais, Kelsey Grammer, Cheech Marin, Tommy Chong, David Cross, John Mahoney, David Hyde Pierce, Zach Braff, Robert De Niro, Macaulay Culkin, Seth Green, Breckin Meyer, Vincent Pastore, Helena Bonham Carter, David Spade and Seth MacFarlane.

Voice cast[]

Main articles: List of Ed, Edd n Eddy and Foster's Home for Imaginary Friends characters

Main characters from Ed, Edd n Eddy[]

Bill Farmer as Ed

Samuel Vincent as Edd/Double D

Billy West as Eddy

Supporting characters from Ed, Edd n Eddy[]

Tom Kenny as Jonny 2x4

Charlie Schlatter as Kevin

Russi Taylor as Jimmy

Kath Soucie as Sarah

Dee Bradley Baker as Rolf

Kerri Kenney-Silver as Nazz

Pat Musick as Lee Kanker

Tress MacNeille as Marie Kanker

Tara Strong as May Kanker

Keith David as the voice of the narrator

Foster's Home for Imaginary Friends[]

Andrea Libman as Fluffer Nutter, A pink-colored squirrel friend who wears a pink bow on her head.

Phil LaMarr as Jackie Khones, A one-eyed, green-colored, stick-shaped friend.

Dana Snyder as Bloppy Pants, A gray-colored cat friend who is dressed in a coat and a scarf, along with mess-upped whiskers.

Jim Conroy as Billy the Squid, A pink squid friend.

Rob Paulsen as Yogi Boo Boo, A green imaginary friend with yellow spots.

Ricky Gervais as Sunset Junction, A blue-colored bear friend.

Guest stars[]

Kelsey Grammer as Jeremy Marksworth (Ed, Edd n Eddy)

Cheech Marin and Tommy Chong as Jeremy Marksworth's Henchman (Ed, Edd n Eddy)

David Cross as Roger (Ed, Edd n Eddy)

John Mahoney, David Hyde Pierce and Richard Kind as Roger's Friends (Ed, Edd n Eddy)

Dan Aykroyd as Jason Woods (Foster's Home for Imaginary Friends)

Macaulay Culkin, Seth Green and Breckin Meyer as Jason Woods' minions (Foster's Home for Imaginary Friends)

Vincent Pastore as Jason Woods' brother (Foster's Home for Imaginary Friends)

Helena Bonham Carter as Edna (Foster's Home for Imaginary Friends)

David Spade as Officer Wilson (Foster's Home for Imaginary Friends)

Rainn Wilson as Mr. Tuck, Jeremy Marksworth's former owner (Ed, Edd n Eddy)

Seth MacFarlane as The Bus Driver, the robot who can drive. (Foster's Home for Imaginary Friends)

Additional Voices[]

Production[]

Development[]

Danny Antonucci, Dan Sioui, and Ruth Vincent started working on the film in 1998 when Antonucci came up with the idea during production of the show. In June 2000, Variety reported that Antonucci would direct in his directorial debut on an traditional 2-D hand-drawn animated comedy crossover film based on the television series Ed, Edd n Eddy and Foster's Home for Imaginary Friends. It was once expected to be released in 2003 under the title The Eds' Meet the Imaginary Friends, Production began in July 2001.

In October 2002, Warner Bros. Feature Animation (Warner Bros. Pictures) and Cartoon Network revealed the film's new title to be The Ed, Edd n Eddy Movie, which would be produced by Antonucci, with Jono Howard, Sioui, and Vincent writing the film's screenplay. In May 2003, it was announced that Mike Kubat would be added as a story writer.

Casting[]

Animation[]

The film was animated in-house by Cartoon Network Studios in Burbank, California and a.k.a. Cartoon in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada.

Toon Boom Animation's Toon Boom Harmony software was used as the main software package for the production of the film. The character animators found some difficulty with this approach, and decided to use traditional paper and pencil drawings, which were then scanned into the computer systems, for The Ed, Edd n Eddy Movie. Pencil on paper animation sequences would be digitally inked-and-painted, enhanced and composited into backgrounds using Toon Boom Harmony.

The character animation was done on paper without going through the clean-up animation department, and scanned directly into Photoshop. Danny Antonucci explained that they went paperless for The Ed, Edd n Eddy Movie to help them introduce the 2D pipeline. The artwork was then enhanced to affect the appearance of painted strokes and fills, and combined with backgrounds, using Adobe After Effects.

The visual effects and backgrounds for the film were created digitally using Wacom Cintiq tablet displays. The backgrounds were painted digitally using Adobe Photoshop, and many of the architectural elements were based upon 3D models built in Alias|Wavefront, Autodesk, Blender, Marionette, Maya, Mental Images and Softimage 3D. Much of the clean-up animation, digital ink-and-paint, and compositing were outsourced to second-party companies around the world.

The film's animation were done all domestically and overseas at Rough Draft Korea in Seoul, South Korea, Ontario, Canada, with additional animation done at Rough Draft Feature Animation in Seoul, South Korea and Los Angeles, California, Don Bluth Feature Animation in New York City, New York, United States, A. Film Production in Copenhagen, Denmark, Yowza! Animation in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, Character Builders, Inc. in Columbus, Fil-Cartoons in Manila, Philippines, Funbag Animation Studios in Ottawa, Heart of Texas Productions, Inc. in Austin, Texas, Kroyer Films, Inc. in Hollywood, California, and Mr. Big Cartoons in Sydney, Australia and additional CGI animation done at Blur Studio in Culver City, California, United States.

Release[]

The Ed, Edd n Eddy Movie was originally going to be released in 2003; however, in February of 2001, the date was changed to 2004. This happened because Cartoon Network released Hi Hi Puffy AmiYumi in July 2003, thus pushing The Ed, Edd n Eddy Movie to 2004. The song Hug Me by Baha Men and LL Cool J featuring Will Smith was used to help promote the movie.

The Ed, Edd n Eddy Movie premiered at Grauman's Chinese Theatre on November 5, 2004, and was theatrically released on November 19, 2004, in the worldwide release. The film's theatrical release was preceded by It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad Foster's, a Foster's Home for Imaginary Friends short.

MPAA rating[]

The Ed, Edd n Eddy Movie is rated PG for parental guidance.

Marketing[]

The film's first teaser trailer was released with Hi Hi Puffy AmiYumi on July 18, 2003, and was also shown before Freaky Friday, Teacher's Pet, Secondhand Lions, Brother Bear, Elf, Looney Tunes: Back in Action, Dr. Seuss' The Cat in the Hat and The Haunted Mansion.

Another teaser trailer was released with Dusk and Dawn on December 19, 2003, and was shown before Cheaper by the Dozen, Peter Pan, Miracle, Confessions of a Teenage Drama Queen, The Pet Squadron, Scooby-Doo 2: Monsters Unleashed, Home on the Range and Ella Enchanted.

The first theatrical trailer was attached on April 23, 2004, and was shown Shrek 2, Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, Garfield: The Movie, Around the World in 80 Days, Steamin' Hot, Garfield: The Movie, Napoleon Dynamite and Thunderbirds.

The second theatrical trailer was released with Computeropolis on July 2, 2004, and was shown before Sleepover, A Cinderella Story, Spider-Man 2, Summer, Yu-Gi-Oh!: The Movie, The Princess Diaries 2: Royal Engagement, Shark Tale, Raise Your Voice and The Incredibles.

TV Spots began to air between October and December 2004.

The film was backed by a large marketing campaign, with various merchandise becoming available throughout 2004, Such as:

McDonald's, having put 12 toys for their Happy Meals in the US and UK. The toys are Ed, Edd, Eddy, Fluffer Nutter, Jackie Khones, Bloppy Pants, Yogi Boo Boo, Billy the Squid, Sunset Junction, Jeremy Marksworth, Jason Woods, and Roger.

in the US and UK Mattel release Action-Figures, and Toys (Which is shown on here, along with other characters from the film like Fluffer Nutter, Jackie Khones, Bloppy Pants, Yogi Boo Boo, Billy the Squid, and Sunset Junction)

in the US and UK Kellogg's cereals have one of 12 Wobble Heads including Ed, Edd, Eddy, Fluffer Nutter, Jackie Khones, Bloppy Pants, Yogi Boo Boo, Billy the Squid, Sunset Junction, Jeremy Marksworth, Jason Woods, and Roger.

Home media[]

Main article: The Ed, Edd n Eddy Movie/Home media

The Ed, Edd n Eddy Movie was released in the United States on DVD and VHS on January 4, 2005. The VHS included the "Hug Me" music video by Baha Men and LL Cool J featuring Will Smith. The DVD included a Foster's Home for Imaginary Friends short film titled It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad Foster's, audio commentary, behind-the-scenes featurettes, music videos, production notes, interactive games, and trailers and television spots. The film was released on Blu-ray on May 14, 2013, to promote the 14th Anniversary of the show.

Video game[]

A video game based on the film was published by Midway Games and released on October 27, 2004, for Nintendo GameCube, PlayStation 2, Xbox, Game Boy Advance, and PC.

Critical reception[]

Review aggregate website Rotten Tomatoes gives the film a 73% approval rating based on the 120 reviews, and its average rating is 6.2/10. The critical consensus reads, "The Ed, Edd n Eddy Movie is great for children and teenagers, and interesting for adults. Even the animation is much better than the shows but just the crossover movie." Metacritic, assigns the film a score of 66 out of 100, based on 32 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews". CinemaScore gives the film a "B+" on its A+ to F scale.

Box office[]
